ques: _______ was a beautiful day and my friend and I decided to have a picnic.
A picnic _______ on a summer day can be a wonderful experience.
A _______ happened to us on the way to the picnic.
_______ was driving to the picnic when I had trouble with my tire.
A _______ on a busy road can be a terrible experience.
Fortunately, we didn’t have an _______
_______ were worn-out after changing the tire.
A _______ would have been wonderful, but we couldn’t find one near the road.
I need the suit _______ is in the cleaners.
The boy _______ needed new clothes went shopping.
This jacket, _______ is too small for me, needs to be tailored.
Teachers _______ classes are interesting have many students.
Students _______ study hard are usually successful.
We do not agree. We have conflicting _______
Our points of view are close together; we are more or less in _______
The liberal’s opinion did not agree with the _______
I must know if you’re on my _______
You are entitled to your opinion. I do not wish to start an _______
If you agree with me, there is no reason for a _______
You have your opinion, and they have _______
The speaker had his point of view, and I had _______
Just as you have a right to your ideas, we have a right to _______
I presented my beliefs, and he presented _______
If you’ll think about my viewpoint, I’ll consider _______
The man and woman were able to settle their quarrel, but his views were different from _______
We are entitled to _______ own opinions.
They finally resolved _______ differences.
I think I'll attend the club meeting _______ (every day, last week, tomorrow)
Did you wear formal clothes to the banquet _______ (last night, all the time, later)
Does he come home for Christmas _______ ? (in 1954, every year, next year)
I think I'll change jobs _______ (a year ago, one of these days, on Sundays)
We're going to take a trip around the world _______ (on Sundays, the day before yesterday, someday)
I have to borrow some money _______ (yesterday, in 1954, every month)
An astronaut will go to the moon _______ (the day before yesterday, in the near future, all the time)
I went to the beauty parlor to get my hair set _______ (The day before yesterday, later, every day)
I take a vacation _______ (every year, last year, next year)
Don’t get mad _______ me. I only wanted to help.
I must figure _______ the problem by myself.
I suggest you tear _______ the letter and begin again.
Please don’t interfere _______ my affairs.
If you don’t agree _______ me, I wish you would say so.
If you don’t listen _______ me, you'll regret it later.
Take my advice and start the letter _______
If you care _______ my opinion, I don’t think you should go.
I’m depending _______ you to help me.
Please come in and sit _______
What point are you trying to get _______ ?
I haven’t thanked you for your kindness _______
You've _______ thanked me many times.
But I _______ haven't thanked you enough.
That’s all right. You don’t have to thank me _______
Has he shown his appreciation _______ ?
Yes, he’s _______ shown his gratitude.
Does he _______ worry you with his problems?
No, he doesn’t bother me _______
explanation: "Yesterday" refers to the day before today. It fits the context of a past event where a beautiful day led to the decision to have a picnic.
"Lunch" refers to a meal eaten in the middle of the day. In the context of a picnic, it specifically highlights the meal aspect of the outing.
"Peculiar thing" refers to something unusual or strange. This fits the context of something unexpected happening on the way to the picnic.
"I" is the correct subject pronoun to indicate the speaker was the one driving when the trouble occurred.
"Blowout" refers to a sudden bursting of a tire. It fits the context of an unexpected and potentially dangerous event on a busy road.
"Accident" refers to an unfortunate event, often involving injury or damage. It fits the context of avoiding a serious problem on the road.
"We" indicates that both the speaker and their friend were tired after the effort of changing the tire.
"Shady place" refers to a spot protected from the sun by shade. It fits the context of needing a comfortable place to rest after changing the tire.
"Which" is used to add information about the noun "suit". It introduces a relative clause specifying the suit that is in the cleaners.
"Who" is a relative pronoun that refers to the subject "boy" and connects the relative clause "who needed new clothes" to the main clause.
"Which" is used to introduce a non-restrictive relative clause, providing additional information about the jacket being too small.
"Whose" is a possessive relative pronoun that indicates the teachers possess the interesting classes. It links the noun "teachers" to the noun "classes".
"Who" is a relative pronoun used to refer to the subject "students" and connects the relative clause "who study hard" to the main clause.
"Viewpoints" refers to the particular attitudes or ways of considering something. In this context, it highlights the differing perspectives that lead to disagreement.
"Agreement" means a mutual arrangement or understanding. Here, it indicates that the points of view are aligned.
"Conservative's" refers to a person with conservative views, typically opposing liberal views. This fits the context of differing political opinions.
"Side" means being aligned or in support of someone or something. Here, it indicates needing to know if the other person is supportive.
"Argument" refers to a heated or contentious exchange of views. It fits the context of wanting to avoid a conflict.
"Conflict" refers to a serious disagreement or argument. If there is agreement, there is no need for conflict.
"Theirs" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to them. It fits the context of contrasting opinions.
"Mine" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to the speaker. It fits the context of contrasting viewpoints.
"Ours" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to us. It fits the context of contrasting rights to opinions.
"His" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to him. It fits the context of contrasting beliefs.
"Yours" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to you. It fits the context of mutual consideration of viewpoints.
"Hers" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to her. It fits the context of contrasting views.
"Our" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to us. It fits the context of the right to opinions.
"Their" is a possessive pronoun referring to something belonging to them. It fits the context of resolving differences.
"Tomorrow" refers to the day after today. It fits the context of planning to attend a meeting in the future.
"Last night" refers to the previous evening. It fits the context of asking about a past event.
"Every year" indicates a recurring event. It fits the context of asking about a regular occurrence during Christmas.
"One of these days" means at some unspecified time in the future. It fits the context of planning to change jobs soon.
"Someday" refers to an unspecified time in the future. It fits the context of planning to take a trip around the world eventually.
"Every month" indicates a recurring event. It fits the context of regularly needing to borrow money.
"In the near future" refers to a time soon to come. It fits the context of a planned space mission to the moon.
"The day before yesterday" refers to two days ago. It fits the context of a past event.
"Every year" indicates a recurring event. It fits the context of regularly taking vacations annually.
"At" is used to indicate the target of the emotion. In this context, it means not to be angry with the speaker.
"Out" is used to indicate solving or understanding something. In this context, it means to solve the problem.
"Up" means to tear something into pieces. In this context, it means to destroy the letter.
"In" is used to indicate involvement or meddling. In this context, it means not to meddle in someone's affairs.
"With" is used to indicate agreement or alignment. In this context, it means to have the same opinion as the speaker.
"To" is used to indicate the direction of attention. In this context, it means to pay attention to the speaker's advice.
"Over" means to start again from the beginning. In this context, it means to rewrite the letter.
"For" is used to indicate interest or concern. In this context, it means to value the speaker's opinion.
"On" is used to indicate reliance or trust. In this context, it means to rely on someone for help.
"Down" is used to indicate the action of taking a seat. In this context, it means to sit on a chair or sofa.
"Across" means to convey or communicate an idea clearly. In this context, it means to make a point understood.
"Yet" is used in negative sentences to indicate that something has not happened up to the present time. It fits the context of not having thanked someone.
"Already" is used to indicate that something has happened before now. It fits the context of having thanked someone multiple times.
"Still" is used to indicate that something continues to be the case. It fits the context of feeling that more thanks are due.
"Anymore" is used to indicate that something is no longer the case. It fits the context of no longer needing to thank someone.
"Yet" is used in questions to indicate that something is expected to happen. It fits the context of asking if appreciation has been shown.
"Already" indicates that something has happened before now. It fits the context of having shown gratitude.
"Still" indicates that something continues to happen. It fits the context of ongoing worry caused by someone's problems.
"Anymore" indicates that something no longer happens. It fits the context of not being bothered by someone any longer.
